F)	Planned Changes to Improve Safety 

The Reinhart Technical Center (RTC), in Richmond, VA, is Carpenter Companys state-of-the-art Research and Development Center.  At RTC, chemists, chemical engineers, and other highly skilled personnel are constantly reviewing and re-inventing the foam pouring process.  RTC personnel has developed and refined the many recipes that Carpenters pouring plants produce every day.  Foremost at RTC is the safety of Carpenters employees, our plants neighbors, and the environment that we live in.  Most of our safety procedures have been developed by RTC experts.  RTC strives daily to make the polyurethane foam pouring process safer.  

At Carpenter  Mt. Airy, we recognize that the post-9/11 world that we live in calls for prudent measures in regards to plant security.  To ensure and maintain a secure facility, Carpenter  Mt. Airy has implemented the following:
	Employees must enter their personalized access code to enter the building.
	All approved visitors must sign our visitors log and are escorted at all times. 
	Before hiring, a background check and drug test is performed on prospective employees.

To forecast the worst-case release scenario of TDI, the NOAAs National Ocean Services ALOHA air dispersion model was used.  The worst-case toxic release scenario was determined to be an instantaneous liquid spill and vaporization of TDI from a railcar queued outdoors into a diked area.  From this ALOHA modeling, it was determined a release rate of 1.1 lbs. per minute for a duration of 60 minutes could occur.  The ALOHA model was also used to estimate the distance to the toxic endpoint. The distance to the toxic endpoint is 0.06 miles (106 yards) which did not extend off-site. Therefore, no public receptors were within the distance to the toxic endpoint.

D)	The Five-Year Accident History

For the five years prior to the submission of this RMP, Carpenter  Mt. Airy has NOT had an accidental release of the regulated substance, Toluene Diisocyanate (TDI), where exposure to the substance, their reaction products, overpressure generated by an explosion involving the substance, or radiant heat generated by a fire involving the substance led to any of the following offsite:  death, injury or response or restoration activities for an exposure of an environmental receptor.

Toluene diisocyanate (TDI), an 80/20% mix of the 2, 4 and 2, 6 isomers, is used as a reactant in the foam pouring process.  TDI is received primarily via railcars that contain approximately 190,000 pounds of product.  These railcars are queued outdoors.  Transfer hoses and related equipment are connected and the unloading process begins.  TDI is transferred from the railcar to storage tanks located in the interior tank farm.  These TDI tanks are seated in concrete secondary containment structures that can completely capture the tanks content in the event of a total tank failure.  TDI is pumped from the storage tanks through a strainer, filter, and heat exchanger before arriving into the mixing head.  In the mixing head, TDI is blended with polyol, water, carbon dioxide (CO2), pigments, fillers, and other minor components.  The resulting chemical reaction produces polyurethane foam.

C)	The General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps 

Carpenter  Mt. Airy abides fully with EPAs Clean Air Act Section 112(r):  Accidental Release Prevention/Risk Management Plan Rule.  Carpenter  Mt. Airys Risk Management Plan will be subject to dedicated inspections by the North Carolina Department of Environmental Quality - Division of Air Quality.  Further, this facility is in good standing with all of the N.C. DEQs Divisions (Air Quality, Water Quality, and the Departments of Waste Management and Storm Water.)

Concerning TDI, the storage tanks are equipped with electronic overfill alarms with automatic pump shutoff and are vented through a bank of activated charcoal filters to remove all of the TDI vapors.  The foam pouring process is equipped with a continuous TDI vapor monitor with electronic and audible alarms.

An Emergency Response Plan for Carpenter - Mt. Airy has been developed.  This Plan includes the procedures for informing applicable Emergency Response agencies should an accidental release occur.  Also, the Emergency Response Plan provides guidelines for the Emergency Coordinator(s) to respond to all emergency situations.  These guidelines include:  location of all hazardous chemicals and other substances, listing of alternate Emergency Coordinators with contact information, assembly of Carpenter  Mt. Airys employee-staffed Spill Team, telephone numbers for all emergency response agencies and the closest local hospital, and provides the division manager or his designee the government agencies that must be notified during and after an emergency situation has abated.  

In the event of a major release of a hazardous substance, all U.S. Carpenter locations have contracted with Clean Harbors Environmental Services, Inc. to coordinate and execute a massive clean-up effort.

Executive Summary---Risk Management Plan for Carpenter Company, Mt. Airy, NC---40 CFR 68.155

In 1948, E. Rhodes Carpenter began distributing cushioning materials to the furniture industry.  By 1956, Carpenters company began manufacturing flexible polyurethane foam marketed to the furniture and home furnishings industries.  In 1962, Carpenter built the first continuous foam pouring line in Richmond, VA.  Due to Carpenters hard work, honesty, and integrity his company grew rapidly.  Since inception, Carpenter Co. has been an industry leader in the markets served, by opening new manufacturing facilities and acquiring existing companies to meet customer demands.  This allowed Carpenter Co. to grow into the largest producer of polyurethane foam in the world.  On December 1, 2023, Carpenter Co. acquired NCFI Polyurethanes in Mt. Airy, NC and changed its name to Carpenter Co.  Mt. Airy, NC. Through its polyurethane foam pouring process the facility is subject to the Environmental Protection Agencys (EPA) Risk Management Plan Rule.

The information required from facilities under the RMP rule helps local fire, police, and emergency response personnel prepare for and respond to chemical emergencies.  Making RMPs available to the public also fosters communication and awareness to improve accident prevention and emergency response practices at the local level.  The RMP rule requires companies that use certain toxic and flammable chemicals to develop a Risk Management Plan.   

With this acquisition, Carpenter Co.  Mt. Airy, NC, will eliminate the use of Pentane (the sole flammable RMP chemical.)  The change in ownership and the removal of Pentane necessitates this RMP submittal.
